elements.2211.03245_ec3a32ac4f829346444e2fcbb2d66: We use a sticky particle method to show global existence of (energy) conservative sticky
elements.2211.03245_fbc320830a0b54b81744617719167: -peakon solutions to the modified Camassa-Holm equation
elements.2211.03245_53839e63de307fa1b4f99dbdebc02: A dispersion regularization is provided as a selection principle for the uniqueness of conservative
elements.2211.03245_dfd526fa73a2ce88c4919b3c8b03e: The dispersion limit avoids the collision between peakons, and numerical results show that the dispersion limit is exactly the sticky peakons
elements.2211.03245_de5767fb6b5072e3848735527e71e: At last, when the splitting of peakons is allowed, we give an example to show the non-uniqueness of conservative solutions.
elements.2211.03245_23af6b332a090fb98682b9c025b57: In this paper, we are going to study the (energy) conservative peakons of the modified Camassa-Holm (mCH) equation:
elements.2211.03245_fa705a5bd17804e46eca47022abac: This equation is an integrable system
elements.2211.03245_aee20a7fc67f46dbd9a1ba4b5f77b: Physically, the mCH equation models the unidirectional propagation of surface waves in shallow water over a flat bottom
elements.2211.03245_346ca79d8bddaa09fadac2008267f: represents the free surface elevation in dimensionless variables
elements.2211.03245_d6ebd7506b3c271a0ad082b2ba63e: It was rediscovered from the two-dimensional Euler equations
elements.2211.03245_dd7cf998f63645afe22fc1df997a4: The mCH equation was also shown to arise from an intrinsic (arc-length preserving) invariant planar curve flow in Euclidean geometry
elements.2211.03245_1adc5fd02ac00f0637325fb7fa844: Moreover, applying tri-Hamiltonian duality method to the bi-Hamiltonian representation of the KdV and the modified KdV equations leads to the Camassa-Holm (CH) equation
elements.2211.03245_43b47f5cad76c9fb1ef58aa4d05fb: This is also one of the reason why we call
elements.2211.03245_963f340e66f8f9c57da7daa4a2982: This paper concerns the special weak solutions to the mCH equation, which are called peakons and they can be represented by the fundamental solution
elements.2211.03245_2cb08ac0fbb781231f7279475a76d: These solutions are also referred to as the
elements.2211.03245_b401789df705e930f7aa267e04099: Let us compare the mCH equation
elements.2211.03245_045f6b77622fa0a5888a89852a853: and introduce the weak solutions to the CH equation first to get a better understanding about the special structures for weak solutions to the mCH equation
elements.2211.03245_2282f5f8d43f9a11e5d0ddd3764a1: Both the CH equation and the mCH equation are integrable systems and they share lots of similarities:
elements.2211.03245_efb0d17501c29fbadbd525eaa5eec: The energy below is conserved for the strong solutions of these two equations:
elements.2211.03245_5c28dcf729da4da6a66b059bb3911: Both of these two equations possess smooth solutions that develop singularities in finite time; see
elements.2211.03245_b6353563065a3c7a84df8cc3d6454: Comparing with smooth solitons for the KdV equation and the modified KdV equation, the solitons given by
elements.2211.03245_5a4c5aa360b0bd5d74c9fc5b5b9e7: for the CH equation and the mCH equation are not smooth, which are called peakons
elements.2211.03245_669ad4af92c2b7e8fd23856a8b1fb: Moreover, the peakons are weak solutions to these two equations.
elements.2211.03245_41256ab92f7ddc4a07be6d1641429: The CH equation and the mCH equation also have lots of discrepancies:
